title: Pensioner forced to go to toilet in bucket after being left with no loo for months
text:

A pensioner has been forced to go to the loo in a bucket after the council left her with no toilet in her bungalow.

Margaret Knight says she feels like a prisoner in her own home and has to visit a neighbour daily to empty her bucket.

Hours after calling Birmingham Live in desperation, she was finally sitting pretty at last in her home near Frankley.

The 68-year-old mother of four and grandmother of 11, said: "I've been without a toilet for weeks since August - it's been absolutely horrendous especially with the rain lashing down as well.

"I've reported the issue several times to the council but nothing happened.

"I was so desperate to go to my own toilet again I thought I would call Birmingham Live to see if they could help."

(Image: BPM Media)

Birmingham City Council has since issued an apology.

Mrs Knight said: "Within hours of speaking to you, a man came round last night with a portable toilet that fits in my bathroom," she said.

"Two men in different vans have come round to try to fix the problem.

"They have taken the old toilet out and are coming back to put a new one in.

"In the future, they might return to tackle the roots of a bush where my bathroom is. I can't thank you enough for helping me - I can now get rid of the bucket."

Mrs Knight says she first reported her toilet problem in August when the waste pipe became blocked.

Attempts by workmen to plunge the loo appeared to work - but the problem would always return within two hours.

Mrs Knight said Severn Trent investigated the situation with dye but concluded that roots had broken a pipe on her property's side of the public boundary.

Severn Trent had said it would not fix the issue there because the source was not on its land.

When a council property is affected, Severn Trent says it is up to the local authority to do the work.

Mrs Knight said that despite reporting the issue to Birmingham City Council several times, and having a reference number, the problem was not fixed.

(Image: Darren Quinton/Birmingham Live)

Mrs Knight said it was only thanks to the goodwill of her next door neighbour that she had been able to remain living at home for the duration of the blockage.

"I've been using a bucket and taking it next door to empty it," she said.

"It was wonderful to get up today to know that I wouldn't have to run straight round. I can't believe that workmen have come to fix the blockage.

"I've lived here for four years and not had a problem before and I do love this house apart from this."

Mrs Knight said she had to retire because of ill health.

She said she used to work in mental health but now has arthritis in her knees and as a sufferer of COPD was often at risk of being hospitalised.

"Every time I've rung up the council, I feel I can't shout at the people at the other end of the phone to do something as I know it's not their fault," she said.

"But I have got a bit angry with them sometimes and I've had to apologise. That's all I could do."

Birmingham City Council apologised for not providing Mrs Knight with a portable toilet after discovering that initial attempts to repair the problem were not successful because of 'roots blocking the drainage system'.

In written statement, the council said: "We have offered our sincere apologies to Mrs Knight for the circumstances that have left her temporarily without adequate facilities.

"We have more than 62,000 tenants all of who we aim to provide with a first-class service.

"On this occasion, we, and the contractor we employ, have fallen short of the standards we would expect and are looking to rectify the situation as soon as possible.”
description: Margaret Knight from Birmingham had to visit a neighbour's home daily to empty her bucket of waste
